awd_titl_txt: Dimensions:  Collaborative Research:  the role of microbial biodiversity in controlling nitrous oxide emissions from soils
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite the vast amount of microbial biodiversity on Earth, the links among the number of microbial species, their genetic diversity, and ecosystem function remain poorly understood. Soils play an important role in sustaining human health. Therefore, it is particularly important to understand the function of the large number of bacterial species in the soil. To provide new insights into the relationship between microbial species and soil function, this project will focus on the reduction of a potent greenhouse gas called nitrous oxide. The reduction of nitrous oxide is a key function of soil microbes. This reduction step determines how much of this greenhouse gas is emitted to the atmosphere from the soil. The recent discovery of a new set of genes, organisms, and pathways that reduce nitrous oxide provides an opportunity to make progress on understanding this function. This project will train undergraduate students and graduate students, including individuals from under-represented groups from Puerto Rico. The training would include workshops, research opportunities, and a Research Experience for Undergraduates program at three institutions. The project also provides outreach opportunities to the general public through established K to Gray programs. Finally, the research from this study will provide society benefits in two ways. First, it will provide a mechanistic understanding of the controls on the production of an important greenhouse gas (nitrous oxide). Second, it will help understand an important loss pathway of nitrogen, the single most limiting nutrient on Earth.

This project will test the hypothesis that the amount of taxonomic and genetic diversity in the nitrous oxide reductase gene is necessary for specialization due to different substrate and environmental conditions in the soil. The ultimate goal is to predict both nitrous oxide reduction rates and nitrous oxide emissions from the genetic and phylogenetic diversity of soil microbes. The proposal will focus on two study sites- one in Illinois and one in Puerto Rico- and measure the abundances and activities of nitrous oxide-reducing taxa and genes in the soils. Simultaneous measurements of nitrous oxide emission rates in a variety of environmental conditions such as temperature, moisture, and nutrient levels, will allow the biotic and abiotic drivers of this reaction to be separated. The predicted rates of nitrous oxide consumption from a multivariate statistical analysis will be tested with independently measured rates by isotope-based methodology. This will allow assessment of the robust model of the microbial and environmental controls of the fate of nitrous oxide.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Dimensions: Collaborative Research: the role of microbial biodiversity in controlling nitrous oxide emissions from soils

Anthropogenic activities, foremost the broad application of synthetic nitrogen (N) fertilizers, introduce large amounts of reactive N (e.g., ammonium and nitrate) into the environment. Plants take up reactive N, but microbial and coupled biotic-abiotic processes convert substantial amounts to N2O, a potent greenhouse gas that also destroys the ozone layer. Current N2O sources outpace N2O sinks, emphasizing the need for comprehensive understanding of processes that consume N2O. The major sink for N2O are microorganisms expressing clade I or clade II N2O reductase (N2OR), and increasing N2OR activity is a promising approach for mitigating N2O emissions. Such an emission control strategy requires a comprehensive understanding of the responses of N2O-reducing microorganisms to environmental parameters such as soil pH, and the functional diversity N2ORs. Microbial N2O reduction has been studied extensively at circumneutral pH (~ pH 7), with limited N2O consumption observed under acidic conditions, and the global phenomenon of soil acidification is predicted to increase N2O emissions.

To explore N2O turnover under acidic conditions, soils were collected in the Luquillo Experimental Forest located in the El Yunque National Forest in the northeastern part of Puerto Rico. Laboratory incubations in the presence of N2O at pH 4.5 yielded enrichment cultures that reduced N2O to environmentally benign dinitrogen (N2) gas. Integrated omics and physiological characterization studies revealed interspecies nutritional interactions and identified novel microorganisms implicated in growth-linked N2O reduction at acidic pH (pH 4.5 - 6), highlighting microbial N2O reduction potential in acidic soils.

Interestingly, the cultivation work yielded N2O-reducing enrichment cultures that did not harbor genes encoding known clade I or clade II N2ORs. Integrated physiological, metagenomic, proteomic, and computational studies demonstrated that a novel N2OR protein family catalyzes N2O reduction. The new enzyme catalyst diverges in sequence from known N2ORs but conserves 3-dimensional structural features relevant for converting N2O to environmentally benign N2 gas. The genes encoding the novel N2OR-type occur in divergent bacterial groups with broad geographic distribution, and imply that uncultivated, not-yet-studied microorganisms constitute an important N2O sink.

Students characterizing various enrichment cultures noticed a profound impact of N2O on other microbial processes that depend on enzymes using a cobamide co-factor (i.e., ‘vitamin B12’). The quick chemical reaction of N2O with the super-reduced Co(I) of the cobamide had been reported; however, the impact of N2O on relevant cobamide-dependent microbial processes such as methanogenesis, reductive dechlorination, or methylmercury formation lacked characterization. Detailed kinetic studies revealed strong inhibition of N2O on methanogenesis and reductive dechlorination, and the measured inhibitory constants provide a quantitative framework to refine predictive capabilities of greenhouse gas (methane, N2O) emissions and contaminant (e.g., chlorinated solvents, mercury) fate and transport in soils and aquifers.

To date, the project has produced twenty-eight peer-reviewed publications, including one review article, with more manuscripts in review and under development. Newly generated metagenome, genome, and N2OR sequences have been made available in public repositories. The project provided several graduate and minority undergraduate students multifaceted learning experiences at the interface of microbiology, chemistry, bioinformatics, biotechnology, and environmental engineering. In addition, a workshop organized in 2022 in Adjuntas, Puerto Rico, delivered teaching modules and hands-on experience in cutting-edge microbiome research approaches to more than 30 graduate (M.S.) and undergraduate students.
